hints.content:
###The process

Looking at the graph of the function $y=f(x)$, we notice that it comes in two *pieces*.  

We can come up with an equation for the *piecewise function* if we can come up with an *equation for each piece* of the function, and an *interval* over which each piece is defined.  

In other words, we want to find a function $f$ so that the following is true.

>$ f(x) = \left\{      \begin{array}{lr}        \blueD{\text{Equation of graph on left}}  &\text{ if left interval} \\         \greenD{\text{Equation of graph on right}} &\text{ if right interval}        \end{array}    \right.$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3dfbe7eeb45452cf6d64a888b3d04d45b8d9c056)

An open circle at $(c,d)$ indicates that $c$ *is not included* in the interval associated with that piece, while a closed circle at $(c,d)$ indicates that $c$ *is included* in the interval associated with that piece.

###The left-hand piece

$\blueD{\text{The graph on the left}}$ is $y=\sqrt{9-x^2}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\blueD{\text{The function on the left}}$ is confined  to the interval $-3 \leq x < 3 $ or $-3\leq x \leq3 $.  The former is an option provided that $x=3$ is in the interval of the second piece.   [[☃ explanation 2]]

options.explanation:
Notice that the graph of the function on the right is the top portion of a circle with center $(0,0)$ and radius $3$.

Since we know that $x^2+y^2=r^2$ is an equation for *full* circle with center $(0,0)$ and radius $r$, it follows that the equation for the full circle containing the given semicircle is $x^2+y^2=9$.

We can solve the equation above for $y$.

$\begin{align} x^2+y^2&= 9\\ \\
y^2 &= 9-x^2\\ \\
y&= \pm\sqrt{9-x^2} \end{align}$

Since we only want the top portion of the circle, our equation is $y=\sqrt{9-x^2}$.

Because the point $(3,0)$ is on the graph of $f$, and it is the *joining point* between the two pieces, the value $3$ can be included in the interval of either piece, so long as it is included in at least one of the intervals. 

We can use the answer options to help us make a decision here.

hints.content:
###The right-hand piece

$\greenD{\text{The graph on the right}}$ is $y=-\sqrt{x-3}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\greenD{\text{The function on the right}}$ is  confined to the interval $3\leq x<8$ or $3< x<8$. 
As mentioned above, $x=3$ doesn't necessarily have to be included in this interval, but it has to be included in one of the intervals of the two pieces.

options.explanation:
Notice that the graph of this function has the basic shape of $y=\sqrt{x}$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5220e4c031e1a75fe02982dc43ddbdc79bd25d97)

However, the graph of the function that we are interested in has been shifted right $3$ units and reflected over the $x$-axis.

So if $h(x)=\sqrt{x}$, then the function we are interested in is $y=-h(x-3)$.  

This function is built below:

>$\begin{align}h(x)&=\sqrt{x}\\\\
h(x-3)&=\sqrt{x-3}\\\\
-h(x-3)&=-\sqrt{x-3}\\\\
\end{align}$

Therefore, it follows that $y=-\sqrt{x-3}$.

hints.content:
###Assessing the options

We found the equations of both pieces and their intervals. The only thing left undetermined is whether $x=3$ is included in the interval of the first piece...

$ f(x) =\begin{cases}   \sqrt{9-x^2}&&\text{if } -3\leq x\leq3 \\   -\sqrt{x-3} &&\text{if }3<  x < 8      \end{cases} $  
$$

... or in the interval of the second piece.

$ f(x) =\begin{cases}   \sqrt{9-x^2}&&\text{if } -3\leq x<3 \\     -\sqrt{x-3} &&\text{if }3\leq  x < 8      \end{cases} $  
$$


Of the possible options given above, only the first function is listed as an answer choice.  


Also, it is important to note that the following choice is ***incorrect***, since for this option, $f(3)$ is undefined.



$ f(x) =\begin{cases}   \sqrt{9-x^2}&&\text{if } -3< x<3 \\      -\sqrt{x-3} &&\text{if }3<  x \leq 8      \end{cases} $  
$$

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
In this case, $x=3$ could be included in both intervals since the value of each *piece* at $x=3$ is the same ensuring that $f$ is indeed a function.

>$\sqrt{9-\maroonD 3^2}=0\qquad$ and $\qquad -\sqrt{{\maroonD{3}-3}}=0$

However, it is not customary to see an $x$-value repeated in the intervals, and so it was not listed above or as an answer choice.

hints.content:
###Conclusion

Putting all of this together we get the following piecewise function.

$ f(x) =\begin{cases}  \blueD{ \sqrt{9-x^2}}&&\text{if } -3\leq x\leq3 \\   \\    \greenD{ -\sqrt{x-3}} &&\text{if }3<  x < 8      \end{cases} $  
$$

question.content:
The graph of $y=f(x)$ is shown below.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/98a13da57a026d333468a3cc736c5779188d7c8f)

**Which of the following could be function $f$?**


[[☃ radio 1]]
